conclusion: A shadow lies on the continuation of the straight line that joins the light-source to every point of the object.
If the lamp is moved while the object stays still, each of those straight lines swings round, so the footprint of the shadow both shifts its position on the floor and changes its size/shape.
Forward means toward the viewer (toward the lower edge of the picture).
Above means the lamp is now higher above the ground than it was before.
The lamp goes from a low, rearward position to a higher, forward-overhead position.

premise: The lamp moves forward and upward.
conclusion: Every shadow center slides in the opposite direction to the lamp’s motion, i.e., backward in the picture (away from the viewer, toward the top of the frame).

premise: The lamp moves forward and upward.
conclusion: The taller the object, the farther its shadow moves.
Vertical rays become steeper, and the horizontal reach of every ray becomes shorter.
Each shadow shrinks (its longest dimension gets smaller), and its outline becomes more compact and less elongated.
A taller object still casts a slightly larger patch than a shorter one, but all shadows are reduced compared with the original.
Object height order (largest first) ≈ B (alarm clock) > A (bowl) > C (berry tart) > D (waffle).

premise: Object height order and shadow behavior rules.
conclusion: A (bowl): shadow slides a moderate distance toward the top of the frame and becomes noticeably smaller and rounder.

premise: Object height order and shadow behavior rules.
conclusion: B (alarm clock): slides the farthest of the four and remains the biggest, but its footprint still contracts markedly.

premise: Object height order and shadow behavior rules.
conclusion: C (tart): shifts a little less than A, ends up nearly under the tart, and contracts to a small, almost circular spot.
